name: MXD: True Stories by Mixed Race Writers
description: MXD: True Stories by Mixed Race Writers In this zine, five individual voices come together to discuss their experiences as Mixed-Race people. Writing about living with institutionalized racism and in a society that breaks down identity into simple categories while ignore multifaceted identities.

name: The First 7-inch was Better: How I became an Ex-Punk
description: The First 7-inch was Better: How I became an Ex-Punk Nia writes about her experiences as a punk, her experiences as a punk and subsequent disillusionment. She addresses racism, sexism, and homophobia, as well as other issues she experienced in punk and activist circles, and explores why she left punk.

name: Borderlands
description: Borderlands: Tales from Disputed Territories between race and cultures A collection of short stories, memoirs, drawings, and critical essays on being Mixed-race. Borderlands #2: It's a Family Affair A collection of essays about Mixed-Race families.

name: Skinned Heart
description: Skinned Heart Zine is a Personal Political Mexicana perspective zine dealing with issues such as mental health, health, abusive relationships, race issues, sexual abuse, and generally living and learning. Issues sold separately. Numero Seis: Description coming soon Numero Cinco: (from the author)This zine is a very quick read all about how it feels to deal with mental health at the onset of winter. Not written from a political point of view but more of a stream of consciousness during a rough time. All about dealing with being bi-polar and how it feels to fall apart and attempt to keep it together. Mini collage poster in the middle of the zine. Numero Quatro: About surviving abusive relationships, feeling disconnected from culture and finding a way back, health issues and healthcare and living in the northwest. Numero Tres: The power of female friendships and support; fallouts and exploring the causes; sexism and wanting to learn from the collective pain and miscommunications; being a radical feminist in denial of the abusive relationship she was in; the loss of a few white friends; gardening

name: Show and Tell
description: Show and Tell is a zine made with <3 in Bend, Oregon! Whimsical drawings and sharp writing makes Show and Tell an engaging and hard to put down personal zine. Issues sold separately. SHOW AND TELL #8 The spirituality issue. In this issue, Rachel writes about connecting to nature, mediation, magic, spirituality as an individual act and as a community. Half page legal, B&W with hand colored cover. 40 pages SHOW AND TELL #9 Rural Demons. In this Issue, Rachel writes about death, estrangement, and trying to fine one's place while growing up, yet showcases the beautiful and gentle things in life as well: all the bits and pieces that make life worth living. Half page letter, B&W with hand colored cover. 32 pages SHOW AND TELL #10 In classic Rachel comic diary style, this zine is sweet and sorrowful all at the same time. This issue includes stories about boys singing The Smiths in the rain, omens and dreams. Half page letter, B&W with hand colored cover. 32 pages SHOE AND TAIL (SHOW AND TELL #11) In this issue Rachel tells us all about ten sweet things that happened in 2012. But as always with Show & Tell, sweet things are coupled with sad happenings. Included is an interview with Ira Glass, getting stitches, conversations about love with her brothers, late night miller time, theories on sneezing, dealing with demons and notes on her kitties death. 40 page, Half page letter, B&W with hand colored cover. OFFERINGS OF GRACE AND MISCHIEF (SHOW AND TELL #12) Rachel writes about Late night spontaneous weddings mix with mental health concerns and environmental harm. Communal living and relationships, an interview with Northwest fashion designer Alice Renner, DIY heartbreak kits, Steinbeck's boat sinking, and faking nothing. 40 page, Half page letter, B&W with hand colored cover.

options.name: Offerings of Grace and Mischief (Show and Tell #13)#12

name: Ire Adrift LP
description: Full-length debut album from Ire Adrift (Tacoma/ Seattle). Doom metal meets crust punk in this album filled with power and venom. Fold out cover, lyric sheet included. Six songs about saints,ghosts, incest and love. Neely Bat Chestnut (Mend My Dress Press) is the voice behind this band. Cover art by Julia Gfrörer. Click here to listen

name: Naija Punx (Shotgun Seamstress #6.5)
description: Naija Punx: 4 Interviews with Nigerian-American Punk Rockers A brand new mini issue of Shotgun Seamstress! In this issue, Osa interviewed 4 Nigerian-Americans punk rockers about identity, punk music and life, and family, to name a few things. The result is an engaging and complex zine that rides the line between personal and political, and a perfect companion to the Shotgun Seamstress Anthology. quarter-page sized, B&W, 26 pages

name: Zine Love button pack
description: 5 adorable 1" buttons to show off your zine love. Drawings by Bri Dearest of Motor City Kitty.

name: Purge #3
description: From the Editor:Contained herein is 46 pages of narration, documentation, prose, and poetry written by survivors of sexual assault on the subject of the violence perpetrated against them and their feelings in the aftermath of their abuse. Their contributions are heartening and tragic, poetic and painful, hopeful and devastating. If you’re a survivor yearning to feel less alone, or a (potential) support person for a survivor, please consider picking up a copy of this zine. A lot of heart went into its creation, and these survivors want and deserve to be heard.

name: Summertime: A Graphic Novella in 4 Parts
description: Summertime: A Grapic Novella in 4 parts, is a beautiful, heartbreaking and redemptive tale of sex, violence, punk, love, self-destruction and survival. Not to mentions Ginas drawings, all skillfully done in ball-point pen are just plain awe inspiring. 92 pages, perfect bound, B&W with colour covers, 8.5" x 7" Also offered wholesale to bookstores/ zine distros. Contact us at <MendMyDress@gmail.com

name: Telegram: A Collection of 27 Issues
description: In the Telegram: A Collection of Twenty-Seven Issues zine anthology Maranda tells tales of daily adventures, friendship, gender identity, falling in love with bicycles, getting tattoos, moving out, going crazy, and their experiences with inpatient hospitalizations. They also write about their relationship with their twin sister, and learning how to take care of their mental health within and without conventional institutions, identifying as genderqueer, getting sober, living a creative and meaningful daily life, and finding reasons to keep on going. At its heart and in its guts, Telegram is about seeking magic in the smallest things, staying crazy in a world that wants us to fake sanity or die, and learning how to take good care of ourselves and each other. 5.5x7" paperback, B&W, 447 pages PLEASE NOTE: we have run into issues with Canadian and UK orders getting to their destinations, and suggest that Canadians purchase from Maranda (http://www.etsy.com/listing/117038142/telegram-a-collection-of-27-issues-book) and that European orders be placed from Amazon.com. Also offered wholesale to bookstores/ zine distros. Contact us at <MendMyDress@gmail.com

options.name: Book, Permission to be weirdoster, Button and Sticker

name: Shotgun Seamstress Zine Anthology
description: Shotgun Seamstress Zine Collection will include all six issues of Osa Atoe’s zine, which includes a ton of interviews, reviews, and so much more! Shotgun Seamstress exists for those that realize that punk rock is an idea and a possibility that must be forced open in order to fit everybody that needs it inside. Shotgun Seamstress is for those that understand the necessity of making a refracted reality available to the kids, especially in an era where it seems possible to unearth everything, where there lies no mystery, a barrage of images and icons displayed on computer screens for five seconds until the next thing appears…This is something to hold onto and reread over and over. A six zine blast that manages to blow apart the apathy and restore faith in the idea of punk rock as a strategy for resistance! Creating a separate currency for those that are not interested in replicating boring ideals in underground existences, Shotgun Seamstress is like the best mix tape anyone has ever made, where radical politics are never sidelined for an easier ride, where good times are never in doubt and where subsumed experiences are revealed as real… The Gories and Void, Nasty Facts and X-Ray Spex, Brontez, Vaginal Davis, punk rock. It’s an endless adventure and this is another way in. -Layla Gibbons of Maximum Rocknroll 7"x10" trade paperback, B&W, 233 pages. Also offered wholesale to bookstores/ zine distros. Contact us at <MendMyDress@gmail.com

name: An Ilse Content Anthology
description: Alexis Wolf, a writer originally from Seattle, WA, has been spreading quiet contemplation to those who read her works since the inception of Ilse Content, her literary and perzine, in 2004. Razorcake Magazine wrote “Alexis has an uncanny ability to write about things like nature, relationships, family, and even spirituality, without coming across as sentimental or wholesome… It’s thoughtful, aware, and respectful of the reader… it allows for sadness and strives for small redemption.” This book is an anthology of writings for her first ten issues. 7"x9" trade paperback, B&W, 270 pages Also offered wholesale to bookstores/ zine distros. Contact us at <MendMyDress@gmail.com

name: Mend My Dress: Collected Zines
description: A collection of zines Neelybat wrote in 2005 through 2007. Includes Mend My Dress 1-6, the one shot Dead Stepdad, in English and Spanish and her half of a split called Grit and Glitter. Chestnut’s Zines are well respected in the zine community and her zines cover issues ranging from incest, self-harm, the riot grrrl movement, feminism, friendship, fairytale, and healing as she reflects on her childhood and coming-of-age. 5.25x8" Trade paperback, B&W, 178 pages Also offered wholesale to bookstores/ zine distros. Contact us at <MendMyDress@gmail.com

name: Mend My Dress (new, single page issues)
description: Neelybat Chestnut's most recent zines are one letter sized page, B&W, tri-folded per-zines. They read as part newsletter, part journal entry, and part letter to a dear friend. Issues sold separately. #11 In the eleventh issue of Mend My Dress, Neelybat tells stories of the places she’s traveled in the last year, and the projects she’s worked on. While dealing with the stress of working a full-time day job, running a publishing press, keeping a relationship & a home together, taking care of her animals, and partying, Neelybat packs her bags and flies to Iceland, a place she’s fallen in love with. With her, she brings a good luck charm, a new notebook, and a passport with her new change of name. “My life is not lived here,” she writes. “It is in my mailbox and on the internet.” Each trip she takes, to another city or another country, acts as an escape from her daily life and an attempt to live a dream. Mend My Dress, while melancholy at times, also contains beauty and hope. #11 is quarter letter-sized, 24-pages, B&W. #10 Vol. 1: Neely writes about working towards having a stable life, traveling and falling in love with Los Angeles and what it would potentially mean to take a chance on a new city. #9 Vol. 4:>#9 Vol. 3: Martha Stewart is the Best Roommate Ever. Writings about living alone, pretending to live with Martha Stewart. #9 Vol. 2: Love you so much. Adventures while visiting my boyfriend in Austin, TX. #9 Vol. 1: Writings about being a home owner and fears of too much stuff #8 Vol. 4: I Share a Birthday With Bob Dylan. Little stories about birthdays #8 Vol. 3: Jealousy Kills Girl Love. Stories about trying to overcome girl hate #8 Vol. 2: In this issue, Neely writes about her fertility, her worries about having children, and her birth control issues. A very personal zine #8 Vol. 1: Good/Bad/Ugly/Strong. Personal zine about talking to her old boyfriend's current girlfriend about his abuse history. Also offered wholesale to bookstores/ zine distros. Contact us at <MendMyDress@gmail.com

options.name: #9 Vol. 4: They were all my friends, and they dies
#9 Vol. 3: Martha Stewart is the Best Roommate Ever
#8 Vol. 4: I Share a Birthday With Bob Dylan

name: Collide: On Physical and Mental Illness
description: From the editor: Collide is a collection of essays by those who are living with a physical disability and some form of mental illness. None of this is easy. Discussing these two distinct but intertwined parts of ourselves, the dynamic, conflicting, challenging, hopeful parts of ourselves, is to be doubly vulnerable. It is to reveal the colliding parts of ourselves that are most intimate, and often hidden. Essays include: Finding Meaning in Pain by Maranda Elizabeth (Telegram) Wow by Synthia Nicole (Damaged Mentality) Half and Half by JC (Tributaries) When Disabilities, Dysfunctional Childhoods, and Mental Health Collide by Kerri Radley (Deafula) With cover art from Anna Gk Half letter-sized, B&W, 32 pages

name: Tenacious: Art & Writings from Women in Prison
description:
Tenacious is a zine filled with articles, essays, poetry and art by formerly and currently incarcerated women across the United States. Their works cover subjects like the health care (or lack of health care) system, being HIV-positive inside prison, trying to get an education while in prison, sexual harassment by prison staff and general prison conditions, and giving up children for adoption.

Issue #27 includes a letter about ongoing conditions in Denver Women's Correctional Facility, how prison staff react to holiday spirit, "It Doesn't Matter If It's Election Time": a response to Marianne Brown's piece by a woman incarcerated in Colorado, letters from CeCe McDonald, mental health care in women's prisons, living with HIV in a women's prison.

Half letter-sized, B&W with colour covers

name: Motor City Kitty
description: Motor City Kitty #22: Bri writes about depression and mental health, the ending of a significant relationship, new beginnings, a book list, and a list of things she does to keep from being sad. As always, a reflective and enjoyable read. Quarter letter-size; B&W, 20 pages Motor City Kitty #21: Bri's second zine made at Fight Boredom's Tulip Farm! Writings about her zine tour & Megabus transportation, depression and anxiety, navigating trying situations as a feminist and a survivor of abuse, and making it through another winter. half legal-size; B&W, 20 pages Motor City Kitty #20: Bri answers questions from Telegram #25 about her goals and ideal life. She also writes about being a survivor of abuse, while also being involved in a relationship with someone who is going through an accountability process. Quarter letter-size; B&W, 40 pages Motor City Kitty #19: Bri writes powerful and eloquent stories about her family and her relationship to them and forms of grief, specifically about how her father died from a heroin overdose when she was 13 and how she is dealing with realizing that at this point, she has lived the majority of her life without him. She also shares a story about and being a punk lady at a show at a boys punk club in Montreal. Quarter letter-size; B&W, 48 pages Bri also drew the drawing on the back of our website and does freelance commission work. Her stuff is rad, so let her know if you're interested in commissioning anything.

name: Good To Know
description:
Based in Malaysia, the Good to Know Project are fun zines full of advice and inspiration from artists/illustrators/designers on creativity, business and life.

Issue #8: HELP
"What sort of support do you receive as an artist? What advice would you share with fellow artists about getting help? "This issue has 16 artists who shares about help and support: where they get theirs and how you can too!

B&W, A5 sized, 28 pages, staple-bound.

Issue #9: Rituals & Routines
"Are there rituals or routines that help you get into work mode? What keeps you motivated?" This issue has 15 artists who shares about their routines and rituals to getting things done!

B&W, A5 sized, 24 pages, staple-bound.

name: Not Straight Not White Not Male
description: From the author: “I wrote this zine because there is a lack of media that I can really, truly relate to. It is glaringly obvious that this radical scene is comprised mostly of heteros, of whites, and of males. I am Asian, I am hella gay, and I am female. Disclaimer: I wrote this for me a lot more than I wrote it for you. There is a lack of solution offering, and at the same time a lot rambling, because it is cathartic for me. It is highly anecdotal; I write from experience. Don’t assume that my aim is to educate ignorant fucks. It is not my job to cry and bleed so that they can fucking evolve. 1/2 letter page sized, B&W

name: Tributaries
description: From the Author: Tributaries is a zine about growing up with a physical disability, and how that impacts my experiences with work, tricycle purchases, and love (so far). tributaries #1: on foot surgery, hospitalization, and fear of zombiefication. tributaries #2: on jobs, and finding my way to librarianship. quarter-letter size, B&W, 32 pages tributaries #3:on buying an adult-sized tricycle, stumbling upon historical markers, and how disability can impact a relationship. Half letter page, B&W, 40 pages. tributaries #4: An intro to arthritis in youth. Half letter page, B&W, 22 pages

name: Escape From the Electric City
description:
Poetry, prose, and photos from Stefan Wicks. 

Stefan writes about moving back to Oakland, train rides, relationships, booze, growing up punk, growing older, dreams, and lunchbreaks.  

Stefan takes mundane moments and gives us an accessible and easy to relate to glimpse into his life in poetic verse. 

There is also a small homage to hometown baseball which Colleen smiled at.

Half-letter page, 44 pages, B&W

name: When Language Runs Dry
description: From the When Language Runs Dry editor Finding good information and meaningful dialog about chronic pain can be challenging. Many of the resources out there are very clinical, too general, or are written from outside the pain experience. There are few voices by folks with chronic pain about their struggles and how they keep living as full of a life as possible. This zine attempts to begin to fill the empty space with a diversity of voices telling their stories. We hope that by publishing these essays people will feel a greater sense of permission to speak out. Issue #3: includes 4 new essays, a 15 page comic essay, contributor bios and reading/resource list. Themes include parenting with chronic pain, invisibility and chronic pain, and some ways we've found to survive and thrive in the face of ongoing illness. 1/2 letter sized; Offset with colour covers; 48 pages. Issue #4 includes two prose pieces exploring chronic pain as it intersects with mental illness and identity, a workshop piece about self care, and a number of pieces of poetry. 1/2 letter sized; Offset with colour covers; 44 pages.

name: Invincible Summer / Clutch
description:
An annual split zine from Nicole J. Georges and Clutch. Everyday adventures in comic form!

Invincible Summer #21/ Clutch #24

In this issue, Nicole teaches kids every day, hopes to get some chickens, goes to see Alison Bechdel read in Portland, and sweats over her upcoming graphic novel.

Clutch seems genuinely happy in this issue, hanging out in a hammock with a lady, attending the Toronto Comic & Art Festival, tries to get Nicole to write a children's book, and works on his own graphic novel with friend MK Reed.

7"x7", 32 pages, Orange Ink.

name: Bad Room Mate Zine
description:
A compilation comic zine edited by Nicole J. Georges of Invincible Summer that puts a whole lotta bad roommates in one place. Featuring hysterical happenings and cringe-inducing awkward moments, Bad Room Mate is sure to make you remember the very worst people you've ever lived with in your life, and might even make you feel not so bad about some of your own worst room mate stories. 
 
Featuring "Food stealing, Mormon rights of passage, poorly behaved animals, and all sorts of stories depicting all sorts of bodily fluids"

half-legal sized, 72 pages, B&W

name: The Worst: A Compilation Zine on Grief and Loss
description: THE WORST #1: An intense compilation of grief stories. There are few dialogs in radical communities about grief, death and dying. The subject of death causes most people, even radicals who see themselves as great communicators, to freeze up, or nervously change the subject. "The Worst" is attempting to change that, by helping people start a dialog about loss, so that no one has to suffer silently. There are so many different stories in here, about mothers, fathers, partners, and pets, who've died and left a hole in the lives of others. All these different authors have really come up with something that although sad, helps the grieving feel a little less alone. Screen printed cover, B&W inside. Half legal size, 84 pages. THE WORST #2: Features art and writing from 16 contributors (one of them Miss C. Bean, one half of Mend My Dress Press) about their experiences with death and grief. Themes range from loss of parents, partners, grandparents, and children to friends and community members, and the zine includes a resource list and silk-screened patch with an awesome Audre Lorde quote on it. Each cover is hand printed. B&W inside. Half-page legal sized. 64 pages. THE WORST #3 Features pieces from 22 contributors exploring radical, DIY, activist and community responses to grief and loss. This issue includes submissions exploring loss due to suicide and violence, complicated and disenfranchised grief, loss of siblings, parents, friends, and mentors, and anticipation of a loss during prolonged illness. Also includes an interview with a social center about their memorial altar, tips for how to write about the tuff stuff, and an updated resource list. Each cover is hand printed. B&W inside. Half-page legal sized. 64 pages.

name: Uncharted Waters
description: A perzine by Miss C. Bean, one of the co-founders of Mend My Dress Press. Inspired by her life, watercolour crayons and chart drawing. Uncharted Waters #1: Goodbye High-school Sweetheart In late 2005, years after I graduated high-school, one of my high-school sweethearts unexpectedly passed away. I wrote this zine to help myself remember the details that are slowly fading away with time of our brief fling. It's also about high-school in general, teen angst, bad poetry, trips to the ocean, body image issues and growing up. It's sweet, nostalgic, ultimately sad, and way past overdue. Text and collage heavy, and includes some bar and pie-charts! Quarter-letter sized, B&W with color covers and insert, 40 pages.

name: Pieces #6.5 / My Aim Is True #5
description:
A split between Nichole (Pieces) and Carrie (My Aim is True). Each tells  two very different stories about body issues, though there are many parallel underlying threads. 'Pieces' covers a long-waged battle against acne. 'My Aim is True' covers a struggle with weight. Both are about the need for self-acceptance, self-love, and the people who helped the authors get to these points.

quarter letter size, 82 pages; text heavy, B&W

name: Gender Matters
description:
A collection of 13 stories from trans, genderqueer and genderfluid folks and their experiences with puberty and adolescence. 

Edited and compiled by Carrie Colpitts (My aim is true), Gender Matters is part personal stories (which range from writings from adults looking back on their adolescence to current writings from young adults) meant for trans, genderqueer and genderfluid adolescent, and part resource guide for youth and their allies. 

Heartbreaking and hopeful, Gender Matters is a well edited compilation and resource for young folks and their allies.

name: Chris Montez: Teenage Rockstar
description:
A small humorous mini-comic/ unauthorized biography of Chicano rocker/easy listening artist Chris Montez. 

Lovely drawings and an interesting story of this teenage dream that was a rockstar in the 1950's. 

quarter-letter sized, 12 pages, B&W with red cardstock cover

name: Ghost Lungs
description: Ghost Lungs is a perzine from Em Rose, with haunting and poetic writing that cover topics like trauma and survival, queerness, healing, family, friendship and travel. Ghost Lungs #1: In this issue, Em writes about queerness, names, their grandma dying, failure, desire, & survival. Collage and text heavy. "I was thirteen and I was curious and I wanted to know what it felt like. This body and this life. Never wanted to split veins open and empty - really, I just wanted that tiny ecstasy - you know, the way pain can drive you out of your body and also bring you back." Read the review from Ravenswing zines Quarter-letter sized, B&W with color covers; 46 pages Ghost Lungs #2 Pages are all made from pages of the atlas Em used while driving across the country for the first time. Included are writings from the last five years, and cover such topics as traveling in the states and abroad, moving back to their hometown, the politics of living in a small town vs. a big city, abuse survival, friendship, dreaming, and taking care of ourselves and others. Half-letter size, B&W, 36 pages. Red or black binding.

name: Damaged Mentality
description: In Damaged Mentality, Synthia Nicole writes about the mental and physical effects of sustaining a brain injury. #2.5: Synthia writes about how her injuries occurred, her time in the hospital, surgery, and in physical therapy, and the emotional and physical toll her recovery had on her. She also contemplates the differences between her pre-injury and post-injury self, and grieves for dreams she will now be unable to pursue. Quarter-sized, B&W, 28 pages

name: Little Debbie
description:
Little Debbie-eight songs about sugar, longing. filling the void. dark spooky dance music. neelybat has been enjoying playing it on repeat while applying face paint in her bathroom. also good to sew to, or to listen to when getting ready to paint the whole town red. Cassette tape. Listen to samples here: https://soundcloud.com/little-debbie http://vimeo.com/61316161

Little Debbie - Hypnotized from Miguel Costa Serra on Vimeo.

name: Feel Better: A Zine About Self Love
description:
Feel Better is a small book of tear out cards featuring things we can all to to just feel better. you can put em on the fridge, give them to friends, or use them as post cards. 

These thoughtful collages include such advice as light candles, stay brave, stay glad, cook food and be humble. 

Beautifully printed on a Risograph on heavy cream stock with perforated edges. 

6'x6', 10 pages + cover, color.

name: Stunned Lungs
description: Stunned Lungs is an intensely personal poetry zine by Tara Jay. Their words will rip your heart out and sucker punch you in the gut, as any good poetry should. Issue 1: From the inside cover: Most of the poems in this zine were written at the end of 2010 and the beginning of 2011. They’re about home, and people I’m close to, and about bodies, and about feeling good and feeling hurt and feeling a little disoriented. Poems about gender, queerness, childhood pets, as well as everything listed above. 1/2 letter page, 16 pages, pink or gray covers Issue 2: Poems about Jellyfish, relationships ending and bruises. 1/2 letter page, 10 pages, colour linocut covers, hand sewn binding

name: Reimagining Queer Community
description:
Reimagining queer community is a personal investigation into Rachels evolving relationship to queerness, as well as some of the ways in which i navigate queer spaces around her. some of the topics in this zine include: alienation and estrangement from the queer community, what it means to feel connected, the myth of a cohesive queer community, being a spectator versus being a participant, (personal and shared) queer histories, and potential strategies to build new alliances.

quarter-letter sized, 20 pages, b&w, text heavy

name: You've Got a Friend in Pennsylvania
description: sari (of Hoax and Neither Dollhouses nor Tree Houses: On Living Outside of the Gender Binary.) writes this per-zine about a myriad of things in their life. Heavy and thoughtful, You've Got a Friend in Pennsylvania never ceases to provoke deep reflection. You've Got a Friend in Pennsylvania #6: sari writes about mental health in their life and in their family. They attempt to investigate the traces of anxiety, depression, suicide, and alcoholism in their family's history as well as their own difficulties with these issues. They also include mechanisms they are using to manage and deal with things now and in the future. This is a hefty and heavy assortment of stories, thoughts, and emotions. quarter-letter sized, B&W, 46 pages, text heavy. You've Got a Friend in Pennsylvania #7: On Queerness, Introversion, & Friendship Theory sari writes about what friendships mean to them overall, thoughts on the process of making and keeping friends, how their various identities intersect and affect friendships, the spaces in which friendships are cultivated or cut off, and how they can improve their friendship skills. quarter-letter sized, B&W, 38 pages, text heavy.

options.name: You've Got a Friend in PA #7
You've Got a Friend in PA #6

name: Animal Sex
description: Animal Sex is about...well...Animal Sex! Fully illustrated with lots of wit, snappy humor and interesting facts all about animal sex. More than you ever thought you needed to know, but after you've read these zines you can totally impress all your friends by winning the "animal sex" category on trivia night. ISSUE 1: In which we learn all about dolphins, bed bugs, whiptail lizards, garter snakes, Argentine lake ducks, and more! quarter-letter size, b&w with colour covers, 16 pages ISSUE 2: In which we learn all about slugs, snails, flatworms, fire flies, rove beetles, and more! quarter-letter size, b&w with colour covers, 16 pages ISSUE 3: In which we learn all about sea horses, pipe fish, the laysan albatross, squids, barnacles, and more! quarter-letter size, b&w with colour covers, 16 pages

name: Butch nor Femme #7
description: In Butch nor Femme #7, Lynne writes about monogamy and honesty-specifically around matters of consent, accountability and communication when people in monogamous relationships enter into polyamorous relationships. They also write about trusting and not trusting their body and DC zine fest.

name: Deafula
description: Deafula is a rad zine about a girl and her deafness. Issues sold separately. ISSUE 1: This issue is an introduction to how the author lost her hearing, where she fits in on the deafness spectrum and in the Deaf community, and a helpful list on how to communicate well with any deaf people you might meet. Quarter-letter sized, 24 pages, B&W. ISSUE 2: This issue covers health insurance, and how audiologist visits and hearing aids are never covered by insurance and must be paid for out of pocket by deaf/hard of hearing folks. explores why this might be, and the authors own personal experience with not having insurance coverage for hearing related health costs. Quarter-letter sized, 24 pages, B&W. ISSUE 4: The employment issue. This issue is all about how the authors hearing loss has related to her ability to get a job. stuff about ssdi, ada compliance, and the ways in which being deaf has affected job searching and holding down a job. Quarter-legal sized, 40 pages, B&W. ISSUE 5: "Interview with my Mother." This issue is an interview on what it's like to be a hearing parent raising a deaf child, in the time before the ADA existed, before there was a such thing as an IEP, before institutional or medical guidance really existed, where the only advice the doctor gave her was "well, just try to teach her how to speak." Quarter-letter sized, 40 pages, B&W with block printed cover

name: Pasan Los Dias (Days Go By)
description:
Pasan Los Dias (Days Go By) chronicles teenage angst and cutting teeth among the changes of the Mexican radical/punk community. Ana writes about finding Anarchism, telling her family about being raped, being part of a punk scene where politics and punk went hand in hand, and women in punk. 

1/2 letter page, B&W, 48 pages, text heavy

name: Cheer the Eff Up
description:
Cheer The Eff Up is part fiction/ part non-fiction, and is one of the most successful genre blending pieces of writing I've have read in a long time. It's hard to see where truth ends and fiction begins, which is part of what makes Jonas' writing so accessible. Written as a lteer/ stories/ advice to offspring, Cheer the Eff up makes me regret devouring an issue so fast because there's no more to read after the last page. 

Reading Cheer The Eff Up is like getting to know a warm and inviting friend, and makes you just want to send Jonas a letter and become penpals. (Which, PS, is totally plausible).

CHEER THE EFF UP #1
What part of Cheer The Eff Up is fiction? What isn't? In the end, it doesn't even seem to matter. Issue #1 starts with a letter to an unborn daughter and takes us traveling through Jonas' life. Going to college, making friends, losing friends; supporting friends. Most of the zine is about what happened to all of Jonas' friends after college, and stories about family, peppered with little wisdoms for aforementioned unborn daughter, including "cheer the eff up." There is a  also bittersweet story that ends with a passive aggressive message on a cake. And that's amaze-balls. 

Half-size legal, B&W. And, as Jonas says: "a bunch of pages."

CHEER THE EFF UP #2
Again, Jonas blends truth and fiction, heartbreak and hope into his well written zine. And this time it's a split with his friend Nikki. This issue covers topics like sexual assault, the reasoning behind the "boring-ass" cover design of Cheer The Eff Up (which turns into a surprisingly interesting discussion on generic food and product labeling), people getting old (and I don't mean turning 30. 30 is not old.), communal living, and sending mail to yourself. There is a raw piece on reasons to live, right next to an article about "planking" with ridiculous photos, and then some shit about donuts that I skimmed (for some reason, no one at this press wants to read anything about donuts, but that's another story for another day). At the end of the zine, I was thoroughly cheered the eff up. Well played, Jonas! 

Half-size legal, B&W. And, as Jonas says: "a bunch of pages."

CHEER THE EFF UP #3
Jonas writes about protests and protesting (like the Occupy Movement and NATO protests), and becoming part of a group of friends. He writes about growing older and going to shows. There are scary, sad parts. There and endearing parts. There are funny parts too, but most of the funny parts turn out to be truly frightening, like discussing how Kennedy, the VJ from MTV, turned out to be a creepy conservative. This is my favorite issue so far, but I think my cat disagreed, because she puked on it right after I finished reading it. Trust me, I'm right, and the cat is just wrong. It's a damn good zine. 

Half-size legal, B&W. And, as Jonas says: "a bunch of pages."

CHEER THE EFF UP #4
Jonas writes about depression, anxiety, suicide, fading friendships and new friendships, office jobs and growing older. It's a heavy issue, yet Jonas has infused with humor (for example, when he writes about what he would really like to say at a job interview given the chance...)

(Note: Miss C. Bean wrote these snippets, so the "I" refers to her)

CHEER THE EFF UP #5
Description coming soon!

name: Hoax (Essays on Feminism)
description: Hoax is a compilation zine of essays on feminism. We may not agree with everything in the zine, but reading a bunch of well written essays on peoples experiences and thoughts, Hoax will roll around in your brain for days, and make you think. And that's why we like it! issues sold separately. HOAX #6: Issue #6 is about communication. Essays include: the power & privileges of academic language; feminist reflection on self-care; comedy & comics as an exercise in visibility; re-thinking "righteous anger"; challenging the unspoken commandments of punk; empowerment through getting a tattoo; communicating anger in a subdued manner; feminism & disability on campus; white-washing and the trouble with "people of color" as an umbrella term; scholarly journals & achieving accessibility; the privilege of "progress"; trans* identity & expressing anger; exploring the waves of US feminism; blackness & perceived education; false exposure and "confessional" writing; communicating trans feminine experience; why the n-word is not for white people; recovering from intimate partner violence; rape denial & the cops; "ally" as a false identity; slutwalk & false individualism; handling suicidal thoughts; gay capitalism & the pink dollar market; conscientious language vs. political correctness; women & learned shyness; reframing anti-semitism; survivorship, zine-writing, and disabilities; and the women's land army! also includes original art/comics, prose, feminists we love, and vegan recipes! half-letter size, 76 pages, b&w and super text heavy. HOAX #7 essays include: western feminism’s relationship with Islamic feminism and notions of “visibility”; the concept of a “real” name; zine-making as a feminist process; the importance of daily change for trans*/queer folks; a father’s death and recollections of childhood; creating “life lists” and engaging in active positivity; recovering from an eating disorder; how a haircut released personal baggage and changed social interactions; identities in zines; examining discussions of consent in workshop settings; the “love your body” concept and chronic illness; the Vagina Monologues and questioning the concept of “accessible” feminism; handling a daughter’s self-harming; an interview with fat-positive activists Tasha Fierce & Hanne Blank; white activism as a social performance; questioning sexuality as a young teen; dealing with the loss of a friend; how family history and sexual assault influenced one to stop drinking; pregnancy and parenting while genderqueer; fourth-wave feminism and the incorporation of trans women; the potential of poetry to induce personal change; exploring new models of accountability and forgiveness with an alcoholic friend; reflections from a former CNN journalist about why corporate journalism is not conducive to social change; never before printed interview with lawyer dean spade. also includes original art, feminists we love, vegan recipes, and current feminist heroes! half-letter size, 72 pages, B&W and super text heavy! HOAX #8: Essays include: Trans* identity mirrored in the myth of the Minotaur and concepts of monstrosity, Mythmaking of gender and queerness in one’s personal relationships, The importance of active listening in community organizing, Questioning the werewolf myth as it pertains to queer and female embodiments, Coping with the death of family members and living/being “alone”, A woman of color’s guide to white men, Trans women’s alienation within queer theory and means of articulating their own experiences, Being an archivist and the intricacies of creating history, Czech foundation myths and concepts of gender, Interview with a retired New Jersey Sexual Violent Predator Facility Administrator, Appalachian women’s narratives and experiences in activism opposing mountaintop removal, Exploring one’s abusive past through the story of Persephone, Connecting the myth of the Big Bad Wolf to abusive men in the author’s childhood life, Debunking myths surrounding being an out trans woman and EMT striving to build queer community, Queer cultural amnesia of the AIDS epidemic and a call to refocus queer activism, Investigating the differences between blood-related family and chosen queer family, Reflecting on Roland Barthe’s Mythologies and one’s personal quest as a feminist trans woman, Recovering from sexual assault and racism in heterosexual relationships via creating one’s own narratives, self-care tactics, and self-imposed celibacy, Invoking theoretical patricide by making deliberate changes to oneself to resist resembling an abusive father, and How the blues gave women of color public space to express their histories of abuse and victimization. Also includes poems, a feminist mythology comic, current feminist heroes, and vegan recipes! Half-letter size, B&W, 74 pages, text heavy. Hoax #9 Feminism and Vulnerabilities This issue includes articles: How vulnerability can combat misogyny within trans communities, Vulnerabilities and doors as a queer mixed woman, Nuances of high school experiences, Views on queer identity interrogation, performance, and transparency as a punk zinester, Vulnerabilities of mental health perspectives and lack of intersectionality, Questioning the responsibility of self-agency after “checking out” during sex, Experiences of racism and sexism in a hospital setting and the legitimacy of describing one’s pain, Trans women and solitary confinement, Loss of memory and personal history, critiquing queer/trans* growth narratives, and creating (non-)advice for non-normative teens and young adults, Navigating queer attraction and desire with a history of violence, Dealing with kink, trauma, and complexities of BDSM involvement, Interview Excerpt with Daniela Capistrano, Founder of the POC Zine Project, Examining the necessity of assertiveness for disabled women and asking for accommodations Also includes poems, feminists we love, current feminist heroes, and vegan recipes! 1/2 letter size, black & white, 80 pages, and very text heavy.

name: JANEBILL: Keesha and Joanie and JANE
description:
JANEBILL: Keesha and Joanie and JANE is a fictional story where, in a not-too-distant future, abortion is made illegal in the United States. "Characters, Dialogue and conflict including opinions, memories, and strategic planning filled with hope, disappointment and inspiration."

"As they say in Hollywood, it's all 'based on a true story'– my own true story and the true stories of many, many thousands of women"
-Judith Arcana

Written by Judith Arcana, one of the original "Janes" and featuring an interview with her at the end of the publication 

5"x7.75", 64 pages, full color, offset on glossy paper.

name: Free to Choose: A Guide to Reproductive Freedom
description:
"This is not just another pro-choice zine. It is an introduction to the history of underground abortion and a call to learn our history and to take matters in our own hands. It includes some information on menstrual extraction and a list of resources to learn more. Reproductive choice is not a "right" to be granted or withdrawn." -Eberhardt Press

24 pages, B&W, color cover

name: Reclaiming Our Ancient Wisdom: Herbal Abortion Procedure and Practice for Midwives and Herbalists
description:
"Reclaiming Our Ancient Wisdom is a guide for practiced herbalists and midwives to better serve the women of their communities. Examines safety issues and benefits of herbal abortion; risk and efficacy considerations; criteria and protocol; herbal abortifacients, implantation inhibitors, emmenogogues, oxytocic herbs and more. Beautifully illustrated with botanical drawings from Gerard's Herbal and other early texts." -Eberhardt Press

40 pages, offset print, archival dust jacket

name: Nashville Transit
description:
Kale writes about being trans by sharing stories of his encounters on the Nashville bus system. Written in 2010, and based on notes he took while riding the bus during his first few months of testosterone treatments, this zine lets theory fall by the wayside and in turn we are left with intimate stories of Kale's life. Some stories are heartbreaking, some are heartwarming, some are hilarious, and some are all three at once. 

Contains descriptions of verbal harassment and trans/homophobia and sexism

Half-page letter, B&W, 14 pages

name: Glimmers
description:
in Glimmers, Jane Applesauce offers us "neurotic musings on love, death, magic, astronomy and learning how to be brave in kapitalist america." It's true cut and paste style, with poetic writing floating above image heavy pages, and the end result is something personal, intimate and substantial- all the things a good zine should be. 


24 pages, half-letter size, B&W with fancy coloured covers.

name: Disney Lessons
description: a small zine with lessons I've learned from Disney. Some funny, some snarky, some sweet. All true. quarter-page sized, 48 pages, B&W Also offered wholesale to bookstores/ zine distros. Contact us at <MendMyDress@gmail.com

name: Hold Tight
description:
#1: A beautiful cut-and-paste, written on a typewriter, with pretty flowers in the background per-zine; in which Holly writes about fake feminism, reestablishing contact with her father after 9 years, and her desire not to repeat familial actions in her own life. Also includes a transcendent poems about fathers written by Dick Laurie, a list of things that are awesome, and a zine soundtrack list. 

Quarter sized, B&W, 28 pages.

name: Quiet Club
description: Quiet Club #1: A semi-political per-zine about women's rights and reproductive rights. But it's more that that–it's also about being loud and brave, and putting thoughts out there in open–about not being quiet through writing. quarter-page size, B&W, 20 pages Quiet Club #2: Reflections on being quiet, plus a section on topics Polly would be open to talking about. quarter-page size, B&W, 24 pages Quiet Club #3: About intuition. memories, and Polly re-defining herself. "'I'm trying to take ownership of myself and my creations. My diaries are documents of myself at a specific point in time, and instead of being embarrassed, I can embrace them and in doing so, embrace that 12, 14, 16 year-old me. and love her for who she is." Quarter-page size, B&W, 40 pages

name: The Golden Voice of the Royal Capital
description:
A zine about Cambodia and Ros Sereysothea, a Cambodian rock 'n' roll star in the 1960's-70's, who, at the height of her fame, was murdered by the Khmer Rouge. Part biography, part history lesson about Cambodia and the Khmer Rouge genocide. This fascinating zine is well witen, has lots of pictures, and includes a CD with 16 tracks from the "Golden Voice of the Royal Captital". 

22 pages, B&W, cardstock covers, CD included

name: Miso Kitty
description:
An adorable yet ultimately sad mini-comic about a little kitty in her last days. 

quarter page size, 44 pages, B&W

name: Fascination
description:
Jane Applesauce's zine exploring gender. An image heavy, true cut-and-paste style zine that will make you laugh and ponder. 

24 pages, half-letter size, B&W with fancy coloured covers.

name: A Time of Dying
description:
A small photo book about the last time I visited my great-aunt. Quiet, reflective, and image focused. 

5"x5", full colour, hand-bound, heavy stock linen paper. 

Also offered wholesale to bookstores/ zine distros. Wholesale orders must have a minimum of 10 items, cumulative, so titles can be combined. Wholesale orders of books must have at least 5 books in the order to meet the minimum. Wholesale orders that do not meet the minimum order will be cancelled and refunded. You can also just email us at MendMyDressPress@gmail.com for wholesale info

name: The Discount Bin! Slightly Damaged Zines at a Reduced Cost.
description: Currently in the discount bin we have: Hold Tight with slight water damage and small coffee stains

name: Functionally Ill
description:
Laura-Marie Taylors' introspective, affecting and well-written per-zine in which she examines her daily life  and mental health. 

#14: about her new therapist--what she's like, her methods, how Laura feel about her, core beliefs, psychiatry fads. It's about spirituality, getting rediagnosed with schizo-affective disorder, and anger management.

16 pages, B&W, quarter size, text heavy

name: Fish letters
description:
This is a small zine of unsent letters. Laura-Marie addresses a lost cousin, an ex-husband, two friends, and her mom in these vulnerable and heartrending unsent letters.

12 pages; B&W, quarter-page

name: Suicide Notes
description:
This chapbook consists of suicide notes written to friends and family in poem form. 

Poignant and well-written glimpses of remorse, sorrow, hope and beauty. 

16 pages, B&W, half letter page

name: Stop Touching That
description:
Robyn relays adventures from her first year of teaching art in East Harlem. From various ways to flatten clay, to explaining contemporary religious art, to a no-nonsense nun named Maria, Robyn never fails to make me laugh (to a point where liquid shoots out my nose) and make my heart melt while I let out an audible "awwwww..." all in the span of ten minutes. 

15 pages, 5.5 x 7", black-and-white art

name: Pedal Pusher
description:
A mini-comic of semi-autobiographical stories about driving from coast to coast in a '99 Camry. Camping along the way, finding cowboy boots, diner food, and awkward sleeping arrangements are just some of the adventures Robyn writes about and illustrates in her always amusing style. 

18 pages, 5.5 x 7", black-and-white art, block printed cover

name: 17 Weddings
description:
17 Weddings is a mini comic per-zine in which Robyn recounts her adventures at 17 different weddings. The stories are sweet and hilarious and coupled with endearing drawings. A feel-good read that encompasses lots of awkward wedding moments and include a true bridezilla, terrible posture, bad love songs, relatives that like to party vs. relatives that like to sleep, silent vows and trying to maneuver in a "chicken cutlet" bra. 

18 pages, 5.5 x 7", black-and-white art, gocco-printed cover

name: High on Burning Photographs
description: #6: Ocean's most personal issue. They write about they're time working at child protective services, a lengthy bike trip, some ruminations on how self-publishing is just as valid as getting a MFA, and two essays from an unreleased decade-in-review zine (one about being genderqueer & one about falling in love). half-letter size, B&W, 20 pages #7: In this issue, Ocean writes a lot about the past – about severing ties with her mother, self-injury and regretfully throwing away her zine collection after getting kicked out of her father’s house. But it ain't all bad–there' some sweet stories about friendship and Pittsburgh graffiti half-letter size, B&W, 20 pages #8: In this issue, Ocean writes about a really bad break-up, regaining a sense of self, breaking cycles of abuse, dealing with crises, and thoughts on working as a social worker. Half-letter size, B&W, 16 pages.

name: Shoes Fanzine
description:
#7: A zine of interviews with people who live and work in Vancouver's east side. 

This zine came out right before the Winter Olympics were held in Vancouver, which is pertinent if only because that event displaced many of the people living and working in Van East. Commonly known as the rougher side of town, Shoes Fanzine #7 works on breaking those stereotypes through interviewing the people that can East Van home. Very text heavy. 

68 pages, half-letter page, B&W

name: Basic Paper Airplane
description: Written by Joshua Amberson (From Ms. Valerie Park Distro), Basic Paper Airplane combines haunting poetic language and descriptive writing to share personal and everyday experiences, and sometimes historical facts that you might need when playing trivia games or find yourself in a debate. #5: America and Americana, as seen by Joshua, primarily through car windows. Also offered is a brief essay on the mid-century fad of hula hoops and a list of early patent names. Cursive typewritten font accompanied by B&W photos only add to the beautiful nostalgia Basic Paper Airplane #5 holds. 20 pages, half-letter size, B&W with colour cover #6: "Personal essays and vignettes that span from childhood swarms of bees to drinking cough syrup, kitchen dance parties to hopping trains, breaking out windows in the woods to taking over the streets in elementary school. Along the way there are also essays on Gertrude Stein, huayno music of Peru, Eadweard Muybridge, and The Wright Brothers." 36 pages, half-letter size, B&W.

name: Jane
description:
"Jane was a clandestine abortion counseling service which effectively provided safe, humane services to thousands of women prior to the legalization of abortion in 1973. Jane is an inspiration  a beautiful example of the battles that can be won without begging, of women taking their lives into their own hands and taking responsibility for their actions.” -Eberhardt Press. 

Half-letter size, 60 pages, B&W w/ color covers.

name: Looted
description:
An intriguing photo zine compiling found photos from the Tremé, sold in the French Quarter, from post-Katrina New Orleans.

There is also a brief essay about the history of the Tremé, as well as an offer from the author to return any photographs to their original owner. 

1/2 page letter sized, B&W, 32 pages

name: Disposable Camera
description:
Disposable Camera is written in one day, on a typewriter, and always includes a fold out map in the center. 

Disposable Camera #11: A fictional story about living next door to myself, a paean to the suburbs, with a map of Everysuburb in the center of the zine. A6, B&W.

name: Fern Zine
description:
Fern Zine is a zine all about ferns! Text heavy, with lovely illustrations and photos, Fern Zine is a plethora of history and information. There are excerpts from 19th century fern journals, philosophies on gardening, a piece about the anatomy of ferns, ferns and interior decorating, and the different types of ferns. it's fern heaven! 

A5, B&W, 36 pages

name: “Not ‘Queer’ as in ‘Radical’ but ‘Lesbian’ as in Fuck You”
description:
Rachel (Hoax co-editor) has been mulling over nuanced, and often controversial, questions regarding her association with the lgbt community at large. 

“Not ‘Queer’ as in ‘Radical’ but ‘Lesbian’ as in Fuck You” is a perzine that explores her recent decision to use the word “lesbian” as a substitution for “queer.” She also talk about male domination and sex-right in supposedly “sex positive” queer spaces, the perpetuation of misogynistic troupes and devaluation of lesbian identities within “progressive” and “feminist” communities, owning up to & attempting to combat transphobia that has historically emanated from within lesbian spaces, and queer as hierarchical social capital.

1/4 letter size, text heavy, b&w, 16 pages.

name: Real Life: A Magical Guide to Getting Off the Internet
description:
Real Life: A Magical Guide to Getting Off the Internet is a how-to and story-telling zine by Maranda Elizabeth and their friend Dave Cave. they both realized we'd been spending way too much time online, and that they always ended up feeling worse when they wasted time on the internet. 

Sound familiar? Sometimes it seems like *everyone* is talking about spending less time on the internet, but they're not actually just logging off and walking away. So this zine documents their attempts to do just that, and to encourage YOU to do the same.

name: Live Through This
description:
Live Through This: A Retrospective, the early work of Leigh Riibe (1995-2000) is part of a retrospective of my teenage years. This collateral zine includes some of the photographs in this collection, mixtape art, and hand painted stories from Leigh's life in the nineties. As stated on the first page in the zine, "this is a mixtape archive and a photo herstory of one girl in America." 

30 pages, half letter sized, B&W

name: Neither Doll Houses nor Tree Houses: On Living Outside of the Gender Binary
description:
This 32 page, ½ size, black & white zine focuses on the ups and downs of Sari finding themselves outside of the gender binary. 

From the Author: 

"This three-part zine deals with various facets of gender variant/trans* identity and attempts to both de- and re-construct various questions about my own gender as well as gender in general.

'looking the part: when is gender a drag and when is it not?' focuses on growing up participating in gender-segregated activities, being taunted for being “too masculine” and feeling pushed out of femininity, how masculinity is viewed as inherent and femininity is viewed as a fictitious performance, embracing what many would call “hard femme” throughout my teens years as a defense, and how striving for the “perfect balance” of two genders is not plausible nor an adequate solution.

'not in a vacuum: how transgressive genders lose or gain meanings in various spaces' explains my switch from identifying as a 'grrl' to gender variant/trans*, taking a job in which i was out as trans* (but as a trans man), dealing with being trans*/gender variant and the acceptance or tolerance (or neither) that i feel in various spaces, how my radical friends misgender and disrespect me more often than my non-radical ones, how whiteness permeates trans*/queer identities, and the (non-) accessibility of queer jargon and language.

'none of the above: on choosing the label of no label' explores how coming out has garnered me the most intense gender assumptions yet, dealing with friends who don’t 'get it', my desire to validate my own identity without stepping on the identity of others, how envisioning my gender is a work of science fiction, and a call for white trans*/queer folks to spend more time checking our white privilege."

-Sari

name: Corin Tucker Fanzine
description: Split fanzine by two friends about there love for Corin Tucker. Stories about going to shows and listening to songs over and over alone in our bedrooms. stories of friendship. Comes with a mix cd of the songs we wrote about. half-page letter, B&W, 24 pages. Includes CD. Also offered wholesale to bookstores/ zine distros. Contact us at <MendMyDress@gmail.com

name: Permission To Be Weird Poster
description: Maranda Elizabeth's pretty flyer as a 11x17 poster. Original text, but redone in their favorite color! printed on soft lilac poster paper. Also offered wholesale to bookstores/ zine distros. Contact us at <MendMyDress@gmail.com

options.name: Rolled and shipped in a tube ( $7.5)

name: 500 Ways to Break a Heart
description:
a small perzine about what fills miss c. bean's head on a daily basis- relationships, daily adventures, thinking about mental health, creativity, and other meanderings. 

Issue #7 is about quilting, late night shows, community, her first tattoo, and letters regarding mental health. 

16 pages, B&W, 1/2 page letter

Issue #8 is about various places that have been occupied by people in my life and includes vignettes on an apartment in Flatbush, a produce stand in Hells Kitchen, a Graveyard in eastern Washington, two houses on a small island in the Pacific Northwest, and a few other places. 

16 pages, B&W, 1.2 page letter

name: The Cartography of Farmers Wives
description: The Cartography of Farmers’ Wives: Photography from 1915-1976, is a short paper-back book with sampling of photography from Colleen’s great-grandmother and grandmother. Many of the photographs are landscapes from eastern Washington, though there are a few portraits in this story of a relationship with the land. Photographs collected from the Alberta prairies ranging from 1915-1920, and Eastern Washington farms from 1948-1976

name: A Traveling Song
description:
A Traveling Song is a small paper-back of Hipstamiatic images took on Colleen’s phone on the road-trip her wife and she took when they moved across the country from Washington, D.C., to Seattle, Washington, in 2009. They pretty much drove straight through, and most of the images were taken from the car window while passing through middle America.

6"x6" paperback, full colour, 58 pages.
